blog.name: ao3feed-jonrya
blog.title: AO3feed-Jonrya
blog.description: An automated feed for Jon x Arya fics posted on AO3.

title: Her Wolf-Dragon
description:
by Darkangel3198

She loved him. And because she did, every time he called or knocked, she let him in, preparing to let him down easily and every time, one touch, one small kiss left her breathless and begging for more. Every time, he left her like this. And every time, she got a little worse.

Words: 811, Chapters: 1/1, Language: English

  • Fandoms: A Song of Ice and Fire - George R. R. Martin, A Song of Ice and Fire & Related Fandoms, Game of Thrones (TV)
  • Rating: Mature
  • Warnings: Creator Chose Not To Use Archive Warnings
  • Categories: F/M
  • Characters: Arya Stark, Jon Snow, Sansa Stark
  • Relationships: Jon Snow/Arya Stark, Jon Snow/Sansa Stark
  • Additional Tags: Cheating, Infidelity, Post-Canon, Jon Snow is a Targaryen, Angst, Dark Jon Snow, Sexual Content, Don’t Like Don’t Read, Married Jonsa, affair with sister’s husband, Cousin Incest

blog.name: hypomone535
blog.title: Dream of Ice and Fire
blog.description:
I am a Stark of Winterfell

I am a writer of Jonsa

body:
Not Like the Songs

A northern wolf and hidden dragon

Nothing sweeter to imagine

A bursting tale of deep desire,

This their song of ice and fire…

Once King of the North

Now heir of the realm entire

Once the sword in the darkness

A mix of ice and of fire

And I the dragon could rule the realm

And she my wolf the northern helm

And in my bed the stars outshine

For I am hers and she is mine

And I the wolf that prowls the night

And he my dragon strong in flight

And in my heart the sun succumbs

For across the land winter comes

A northern wolf a hidden dragon

Nothing sweeter to imagine

A bursting tale of deep desire

This our song of ice and fire.

🔥❄️🐺

blog.name: lupinusalbus
blog.title: Lupinus Albus
blog.description:
Speculations about Game of Thrones...
(mostly the show)

summary: The Next Dance of Dragons - Theory (Part I)
title: The Next Dance of Dragons - Theory (Part I)
body:
The Dance of Dragons, only mentioned briefly in the show, but written about extensively in various GRRM books, was a war of succession between different factions of Targaryens (principally between half siblings Rhaenyra Targaryen and Aegon II).   In the HBO series, the war is mentioned by Shireen Baratheon in season 5, episode 9.  She is seen reading and talking about a history book, The Dance of Dragons, A True Telling, before she is burned at the stake by her father.  The events of the war are also mentioned by Joffrey Baratheon in season 3, episode 4, where he delights in telling Maergery Tyrell about the gruesome death of Rhaenyra Targaryen who was fed to a dragon at the end of the conflict. The Dance of the Dragons took place in 129 AC to 131 AC and therefore about 170 years before the events in the series.  The Targaryens lost many dragons in the conflict, and the animals soon went extinct from the world until Daenerys Targaryen hatched three eggs.

The first Dance of the Dragons happened when various nobles sided with one or the other of the rival branches of House Targaryen after the death of Viserys I. In the TV series, Daenerys Targaryen has advanced to Westeros and is in a conquest for the Iron Throne when she meets Jon Snow (now King in the North) and is persuaded that that it is in Westeros’s best interests to seek a truce with Cersei in order to deal with the Army of the Dead to the North of The Wall.  Dany takes her dragons North in order to rescue Jon and others who are attempting to capture a wight to bring to Cersei.  There, one of her dragons, Viserion is killed by the Night King and transformed into a wight dragon.

Central to the plot, is the relationship of Jon Snow to Daenerys Targaryen.  The two become lovers before discovering that they are both Targaryens, and that the line of succession would place Jon (AKA Aegon Targaryen) ahead of Dany as a claimant to the Iron Throne. Genetically, the two are aunt and nephew, because Jon’s biological father is Rhaegar, the older brother of Dany.

The romantic relationship of Jon and Dany was long anticipated by many viewers, and many consider it to the end game that the two will eventually rule together in spite of their incestuous union.  This is because the Targaryens were long known to marry blood relatives, including siblings, in order to preserve the purity of their bloodlines.  On the other hand, most inhabitants of Westerosi society do not look kindly on incestuous relationships, as is evidenced by Jaimie and Cersei Lannister having to keep their sexual relationship secret.  This union is an explosive issue on Game of Thrones, because their three deceased children (including two kings) were the products of incest. 

The catalyst for a second Dance of Dragons is quite straightforward: Dany and Jon learn about his true origins, and their alliance falls apart.  This most likely would not happen because Jon will try to take the throne for himself, but because events will unfold which will make him appear preferable to her as a leader to many key players. Thus, Jon will again have leadership thrust upon him by others, rather than pursuing it for himself.  This has been a key theme in his character arc.

The series has already foreshadowed that Tyrion and Varys have misgivings about Dany since she attacked the Lannisters and executed the Tarleys for refusing to bend the knee.  Varys and Tyrion have a conversation about this in the Throne Room at Dragonstone.  The Tarleys were the father and brother of Samwell Tarley, who is Jon Snow’s best friend.  Neither Samwell nor Jon have yet learned of their deaths, which is probably set to be a dramatic reveal in the first episode of season 8. Dany may react rashly to criticism and anger over her decision by those who are at Winterfell.  This may plant the seeds of dissent or even cause events to spiral out of control as Dany is branded as a sadistic usurper or an insane ruler like her father, “The Mad King.”

Further conflicts may be in the offing as Gendry, an ally of Jon’s and friend of Arya Stark, is revealed to all as the bastard son of Robert Baratheon. Although Gendry did not appear at the Dragon Pit meeting, one can only assume that he is traveling North with the others and headed to Winterfell. Dany will not like that another potential claimant is alive and allied with the Starks. Jaimie Lannister is also headed North.  He is the brother of Cersei and Tyrion and tried to kill Dany during the Loot Train attack. Dany’s misgivings about either of these characters are quite understandable, but in the context of her arrival at the hostile environment of Winterfell their presence could contribute to putting her over the edge.

So a possible scenario is for Daenery’s reputation to be damaged right off the bat.  This, combined with the revelation of Jon’s true bloodline, may break her alliance with him and also cause key players to support Jon.

Genetically, the two are aunt and nephew, because Jon’s biological father is Rhaegar, the older brother of Dany.

The romantic relationship of Jon and Dany was long anticipated by many viewers, and many consider it to the end game that the two will eventually rule together in spite of their incestuous union.  This is because the Targaryens were long known to marry blood relatives, including siblings, in order to preserve the purity of their bloodlines.  On the other hand, most inhabitants of Westerosi society do not look kindly on incestuous relationships, as is evidenced by Jaimie and Cersei Lannister having to keep their sexual relationship secret.  This union is an explosive issue on Game of Thrones, because their three deceased children (including two kings) were the products of incest. 

The catalyst for a second Dance of Dragons is quite straightforward: Dany and Jon learn about his true origins, and their alliance falls apart.  This most likely would not happen because Jon will try to take the throne for himself, but because events will unfold which will make him appear preferable to her as a leader to many key players. Thus, Jon will again have leadership thrust upon him by others, rather than pursuing it for himself.  This has been a key theme in his character arc.

The series has already foreshadowed that Tyrion and Varys have misgivings about Dany since she attacked the Lannisters and executed the Tarleys for refusing to bend the knee.  Varys and Tyrion have a conversation about this in the Throne Room at Dragonstone.  The Tarleys were the father and brother of Samwell Tarley, who is Jon Snow’s best friend.  Neither Samwell nor Jon have yet learned of their deaths, which is probably set to be a dramatic reveal in the first episode of season 8. Dany may react rashly to criticism and anger over her decision by those who are at Winterfell.  This may plant the seeds of dissent or even cause events to spiral out of control as Dany is branded as a sadistic usurper or an insane ruler like her father, “The Mad King.”

Further conflicts may be in the offing as Gendry, an ally of Jon’s and friend of Arya Stark, is revealed to all as the bastard son of Robert Baratheon. Although Gendry did not appear at the Dragon Pit meeting, one can only assume that he is traveling North with the others and headed to Winterfell. Dany will not like that another potential claimant is alive and allied with the Starks. Jaimie Lannister is also headed North.  He is the brother of Cersei and Tyrion and tried to kill Dany during the Loot Train attack. Dany’s misgivings about either of these characters are quite understandable, but in the context of her arrival at the hostile environment of Winterfell their presence could contribute to putting her over the edge.

So a possible scenario is for Daenery’s reputation to be damaged right off the bat.  This, combined with the revelation of Jon’s true bloodline, may break her alliance with him and also cause key players to support Jon.
trail.content:
The Dance of Dragons, only mentioned briefly in the show, but written about extensively in various GRRM books, was a war of succession between different factions of Targaryens (principally between half siblings Rhaenyra Targaryen and Aegon II).   In the HBO series, the war is mentioned by Shireen Baratheon in season 5, episode 9.  She is seen reading and talking about a history book, The Dance of Dragons, A True Telling, before she is burned at the stake by her father.  The events of the war are also mentioned by Joffrey Baratheon in season 3, episode 4, where he delights in telling Maergery Tyrell about the gruesome death of Rhaenyra Targaryen who was fed to a dragon at the end of the conflict. The Dance of the Dragons took place in 129 AC to 131 AC and therefore about 170 years before the events in the series.  The Targaryens lost many dragons in the conflict, and the animals soon went extinct from the world until Daenerys Targaryen hatched three eggs.

The first Dance of the Dragons happened when various nobles sided with one or the other of the rival branches of House Targaryen after the death of Viserys I. In the TV series, Daenerys Targaryen has advanced to Westeros and is in a conquest for the Iron Throne when she meets Jon Snow (now King in the North) and is persuaded that that it is in Westeros’s best interests to seek a truce with Cersei in order to deal with the Army of the Dead to the North of The Wall.  Dany takes her dragons North in order to rescue Jon and others who are attempting to capture a wight to bring to Cersei.  There, one of her dragons, Viserion is killed by the Night King and transformed into a wight dragon.

Central to the plot, is the relationship of Jon Snow to Daenerys Targaryen.  The two become lovers before discovering that they are both Targaryens, and that the line of succession would place Jon (AKA Aegon Targaryen) ahead of Dany as a claimant to the Iron Throne. Genetically, the two are aunt and nephew, because Jon’s biological father is Rhaegar, the older brother of Dany.

The romantic relationship of Jon and Dany was long anticipated by many viewers, and many consider it to the end game that the two will eventually rule together in spite of their incestuous union.  This is because the Targaryens were long known to marry blood relatives, including siblings, in order to preserve the purity of their bloodlines.  On the other hand, most inhabitants of Westerosi society do not look kindly on incestuous relationships, as is evidenced by Jaimie and Cersei Lannister having to keep their sexual relationship secret.  This union is an explosive issue on Game of Thrones, because their three deceased children (including two kings) were the products of incest. 

The catalyst for a second Dance of Dragons is quite straightforward: Dany and Jon learn about his true origins, and their alliance falls apart.  This most likely would not happen because Jon will try to take the throne for himself, but because events will unfold which will make him appear preferable to her as a leader to many key players. Thus, Jon will again have leadership thrust upon him by others, rather than pursuing it for himself.  This has been a key theme in his character arc.

The series has already foreshadowed that Tyrion and Varys have misgivings about Dany since she attacked the Lannisters and executed the Tarleys for refusing to bend the knee.  Varys and Tyrion have a conversation about this in the Throne Room at Dragonstone.  The Tarleys were the father and brother of Samwell Tarley, who is Jon Snow’s best friend.  Neither Samwell nor Jon have yet learned of their deaths, which is probably set to be a dramatic reveal in the first episode of season 8. Dany may react rashly to criticism and anger over her decision by those who are at Winterfell.  This may plant the seeds of dissent or even cause events to spiral out of control as Dany is branded as a sadistic usurper or an insane ruler like her father, “The Mad King.”

Further conflicts may be in the offing as Gendry, an ally of Jon’s and friend of Arya Stark, is revealed to all as the bastard son of Robert Baratheon. Although Gendry did not appear at the Dragon Pit meeting, one can only assume that he is traveling North with the others and headed to Winterfell. Dany will not like that another potential claimant is alive and allied with the Starks. Jaimie Lannister is also headed North.  He is the brother of Cersei and Tyrion and tried to kill Dany during the Loot Train attack. Dany’s misgivings about either of these characters are quite understandable, but in the context of her arrival at the hostile environment of Winterfell their presence could contribute to putting her over the edge.

So a possible scenario is for Daenery’s reputation to be damaged right off the bat.  This, combined with the revelation of Jon’s true bloodline, may break her alliance with him and also cause key players to support Jon.

blog.name: tatticstudio55
blog.title: pro jonerys who likes healthy debates

tags: I repeat Jon Snow defense squad
summary:
I wish people would tone it down with their “Jon was
stupid for not listening to Sansa’s advice during the Battle of the...
body:
I wish people would tone it down with their “Jon was stupid for not listening to Sansa’s advice during the Battle of the Bastards.”

I don’t think it was ever Jon’s intention to not listen to Sansa’s advice.

I don’t think he ever thought “uh, that’s probably what Sansa meant when she told me not to fall for Ramsay’s tricks. To hell with that, I’ll run for Rickon anyway because I know better”.

It’s one thing to be sitting in a tent, with candles and ale, coming to term with the fact that your little brother, who you haven’t seen in years, is held by the country’s biggest murdering psychopathic a*&?hole. Weighting the pro and the con of a rescue attempt and realizing that the con outweighs the pro by far.

It’s another thing to stick to your wisdom when your little brother is running out of his mind toward you. Or even to remember anything at all about your wisdom… or your sister’s.

Had Jon gotten three seconds to gather his thoughts, he probably would’ve worked out Ramsay’s intent for “releasing” Rickon the way he did.

Or maybe not. Not because Jon is stupid, but because of that thing called “blanking out” when you’re put in a highly stressful situation. “Highly stressful” is, of course, a bit of a euphemism here.

Alas, we’ll never know if Sansa would’ve followed her own advice at the critical moment. She was conveniently absent from Rickon’s death scene, so…

summary: Theon thinks he’s going crazy when he agrees to go clean out Robb’s cabin with Jon Snow. They’ve never gotten along, even when...
caption:
Theon thinks he’s going crazy when he agrees to go clean out Robb’s cabin with Jon Snow. They’ve never gotten along, even when Robb was alive to break them apart, and he knows spending a week in the frigid north with Jon Snow is not a good idea. Still, seeing Jon standing there with snowflakes melting in his hair brings back memories and feelings Theon thought were long buried. 

It turns out spending the week together works out very differently than Theon expected.

made for day 1 of @asoiafrarepairs week. 

prompt: snowflakes
